intro: Echeandia imbricata, commonly known as the Mexican sunflower or Mexican lion's mouth, is a flowering plant native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its showy, orange to red composite flowers. The plant typically grows as an annual or perennial herb, reaching heights of up to 1 meter, with hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves. Its flowers bloom in late summer to early autumn, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Echeandia imbricata is often cultivated for its ornamental value and is relatively easy to grow in well-drained soil and full sun.
